subject: RE: [junit] TDD -> FSM and Chess
msgSnippet: I read once that a chess expert will be relatively confused if presented with a chess configuration that is impossible to get to in a real game because it
messageBody:
I read once that a chess expert will be relatively confused if presented
with a chess configuration that is impossible to get to in a real game
because it doesn't match the patterns they are familiar with.

------

This is really not the case. Typically, strong chess players are quite
capable of sizing up most situations and acting accordingly. However, I
think social and physical problems come into play that are more
influential than the position on the board. Yikes, did I just make
another anology. ;)

I suppose the point would be, what good is TDD if your enviroment is not
supportive of the other XP practices. If you constantly have crazy
deadlines, your co-workers are unproductive as pairs, etc. Time and
time again, I see people suggesting jumping into XP with what I like to
call *the coding practices* when really what they need to do is create
the culture to support these practices first.

Just like a chess player who zones out before the game, utilizing
complete focus on the position...

Just an attempt at another interesting thought....

--Ryan


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Scott Stirling
> Sent: Thursday, February 06, 2003 8:18 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] TDD -> FSM
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
> >
> > Scott:
> >
> > Have you identified how a test-driven class implements a FSM? If I
> > give you some code that I test-drove, would you try
> identifying how it
> > is a FSM? That would be very interesting.
>
> I'd be willing to try. I would be interested to have an
> example that's not my own or borrowed out of a book. But I'm
> working with a few book examples right now, trying to sort
> things out and see how far I can take this FSM idea.
>
> Scott S.
>
